articles.headline: Navy SEALs Were Warned Against Reporting Their Chief for War Crimes
articles.snippet: The Navy investigation of a highly decorated platoon leader who now faces court-martial found a subculture that prized aggression and protected wrongdoers.
articles.abstract: The Navy investigation of a highly decorated platoon leader who now faces court-martial found a subculture that prized aggression and protected wrongdoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stabbing a defenseless teenage captive to death. Picking off a school-age girl and an old man from a sniper’s roost. Indiscriminately spraying neighborhoods with rockets and machine-gun fire.

articles.headline: Japan Has a New Emperor. Now It Needs a Software Update.
articles.snippet: It isn’t exactly Y2K, but the country is scrambling to reconcile its systems with the ancient demands of an imperial calendar.
articles.abstract: It isn’t exactly Y2K, but the country is scrambling to reconcile its systems with the ancient demands of an imperial calendar.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Lost data. Emails that disappear into the ether. Servers that never connect.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley, Makiko Inoue and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: On a Day of Funerals in Sri Lanka, Religious Tension Builds
articles.snippet: Amid mass burials for the more than 350 victims of Sunday’s suicide attacks in Sri Lanka, grief began to harden into anger.
articles.abstract: Amid mass burials for the more than 350 victims of Sunday’s suicide attacks in Sri Lanka, grief began to harden into anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEGOMBO, Sri Lanka — The coffins came one by one, some heavy and others unusually light.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Kai Schultz

articles.headline: Stocks Just Hit a Record. Thank the Fed.
articles.snippet: The bull market lives, thanks to the Federal Reserve’s new, more relaxed approach to interest rates.
articles.abstract: The bull market lives, thanks to the Federal Reserve’s new, more relaxed approach to interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy is softening, profit growth is slowing, and a trade war between the United States and China is grinding on.

articles.headline: Is Obstruction an Impeachable Offense? History Says Yes
articles.snippet: In 1974 and 1998, articles of impeachment against Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Bill Clinton focused on the corrupt use of power to frustrate lawful investigations.
articles.abstract: In 1974 and 1998, articles of impeachment against Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Bill Clinton focused on the corrupt use of power to frustrate lawful investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has been consulting the Constitution. In a Twitter post on Monday, he recited part of Article II, Section 4, the provision that allows Congress to remove federal officials who commit “treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors.”

articles.headline: To TV Writers, Pay Fight With Agents Has Another Villain: Wall Street
articles.snippet: As private-equity funds take big stakes in talent firms, the clients feel shortchanged, pointing to conflicts of interest in the packaging of deals.
articles.abstract: As private-equity funds take big stakes in talent firms, the clients feel shortchanged, pointing to conflicts of interest in the packaging of deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hollywood writers began firing their agents en masse this month, their gripes seemed esoteric. They contended that an obscure set of financial arrangements had created conflicts of interest for their agents and squeezed the writers’ earnings.

articles.headline: Blamed for Wildfires, PG&E Seeks Higher Electricity Rates
articles.snippet: The California utility and two others says higher rates are needed to pay for safety improvements and to offset the financial risk of more frequent wildfires.
articles.abstract: The California utility and two others says higher rates are needed to pay for safety improvements and to offset the financial risk of more frequent wildfires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas & Electric has been blamed for starting some of California’s most devastating wildfires. Now it is asking state officials for permission to raise electricity rates to pay for safety improvements and to offset the financial risk of more wildfires.

articles.headline: ISIS Claims Sri Lanka Attacks, and President Vows Shakeup
articles.snippet: If the link to ISIS proves substantial, it would reinforce worries by Western security officials and others that the group remains a potent threat.
articles.abstract: If the link to ISIS proves substantial, it would reinforce worries by Western security officials and others that the group remains a potent threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Tuesday for the coordinated suicide bombings on churches and hotels in Sri Lanka, as the president of the traumatized nation promised to dismiss senior officials who had failed to act on warnings about the attacks.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Dharisha Bastians and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: Blockbuster Battle Between Steven Spielberg and Netflix Fizzles
articles.snippet: Mr. Spielberg, a Hollywood titan for more than four decades, has been cast as an anti-streaming Luddite. The reality is more complex.
articles.abstract: Mr. Spielberg, a Hollywood titan for more than four decades, has been cast as an anti-streaming Luddite. The reality is more complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It has the makings of a great screenplay: As the future of an entire industry hangs in the balance, the ultimate establishment figure — a genius in his fourth decade of domination — goes to battle with a menacing interloper.

articles.headline: In Push for 2020 Election Security, Top Official Was Warned: Don’t Tell Trump
articles.snippet: As homeland security secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen became increasingly worried about Russian attempts to influence the 2020 election. But she couldn’t discuss it at high-level White House meetings.
articles.abstract: As homeland security secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen became increasingly worried about Russian attempts to influence the 2020 election. But she couldn’t discuss it at high-level White House meetings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months before Kirstjen Nielsen was forced to resign, she tried to focus the White House on one of her highest priorities as homeland security secretary: preparing for new and different Russian forms of interference in the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Made in China, Exported to the World: The Surveillance State
articles.snippet: In Ecuador, cameras capture footage to be examined by police and domestic intelligence. The surveillance system’s origin: China.
articles.abstract: In Ecuador, cameras capture footage to be examined by police and domestic intelligence. The surveillance system’s origin: China.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — The squat gray building in Ecuador’s capital commands a sweeping view of the city’s sparkling sprawl, from the high-rises at the base of the Andean valley to the pastel neighborhoods that spill up its mountainsides.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Jonah M. Kessel and Melissa Chan

articles.headline: Boeing Reports Slide in Earnings and Admits Future Is Hazy
articles.snippet: The aviation giant, which is dealing with the fallout from its troubled 737 Max jet, declined to provide its customary full-year sales and profit forecast.
articles.abstract: The aviation giant, which is dealing with the fallout from its troubled 737 Max jet, declined to provide its customary full-year sales and profit forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: The longer Boeing’s 737 Max plane sits idle, grounded indefinitely by regulators around the world after two deadly crashes, the more the company’s bottom line shrinks.

articles.headline: Occidental Bids $38 Billion for Anadarko, Challenging Chevron
articles.snippet: Occidental Petroleum announced a $38 billion bid for Anadarko Petroleum, challenging Chevron for control of the independent oil and gas company.
articles.abstract: Occidental Petroleum announced a $38 billion bid for Anadarko Petroleum, challenging Chevron for control of the independent oil and gas company.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Occidental Petroleum unveiled an audacious $38 billion takeover bid for Anadarko Petroleum on Wednesday, challenging Chevron — a company four times its size — in a battle for dominance of the biggest and most productive oil field in the United States.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Michael J. de la Merced
